definitions.definition: a piece of clothing made to fit the head, often with a brim (= a flat edge that sticks out), usually worn out of doors

examples.text: He placed a battered felt hat on his head.
He pulled his hat down over his face.
The doorman tipped his hat as we entered.
The governor wore a cocked hat trimmed with white feathers.

definitions.definition: a position or role, especially an official or professional role, when you have more than one such role

examples.text: I'm wearing two hats tonight—parent and teacher.
I'm telling you this with my lawyer's hat on, you understand.
The company can't expect me to move my home and family at the drop of a hat.

definitions.definition: to ask somebody for something, especially money, in a very polite way that makes you seem less important
to live in a particular place

examples.text: These multimillion-dollar homes are more than just a place to hang your hat.

definitions.definition: to depend or rely on something

examples.text: The research is interesting, but you cannot hang your hat on it.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think something is very unlikely to happen

examples.text: If she's here on time, I'll eat my hat!

definitions.definition: used to say that you admire somebody very much for something they have done
to keep something secret and not tell anyone else
to be very much better than somebody/something

examples.text: She knocks the rest of the cast into a cocked hat.

definitions.definition: if something such as a name is picked out of a/the hat, it is picked at random from a container into which all the names are put, so that each name has an equal chance of being picked, in a competition, etc.
to collect money from a number of people, for example to buy a present for somebody
to suddenly produce something as a solution to a problem
to say silly things while you are talking about a subject you do not understand
to announce officially that you are going to compete in an election, a competition, etc.

wordOrigin: Old English hætt, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse hǫttr ‘hood’, also to hood.
